content.body: Hmm, "Fetching the image must delay the load event of the element's node document"
is that right
should it delay load event only in case img element is in the document
Hixie: ^
at least the code in Gecko hints that, but haven't tested yet
or no
apparently img is loaded first
smaug____: that’s a weird onload event, you didn’t put it on the actual iframe content, you put it on the node.
JonathanNeal: nothing weird with that load event
that is where is should be when you want to know if something has been loaded to the iframe element
so, if the element has content ready, why would it not display?
what content ready?
hello world
the issue is that accessing contentWindow.document  creates an about:blank document
in other words, the iframe has content, and depending upon when you add it depends on whether or not you can see it?
that doesn’t make any sense, and is not consistent with any other browsing experience on any platform.
but simultaneously appending the iframe to document has started a task to load a new about:blank
since no src means about:blank
JonathanNeal: the issue is very similar to window.open() behavior
as I said earlier, I don't recall what the spec says about this
JonathanNeal: See https://twitter.com/hsivonen 's summary ;)
Is iframe.src supposed to report “” as the src when it does what you say?
don't recall what it is supposed to "report"
but no src is supposed to load an about:blank document
but I don't know what the spec says in case there is already that initial about:blank
Well, do you think my expectations are misaligned with how things should work, or are you telling me what the bug is or both?
"When an iframe element is inserted into a document that has a browsing context, the user agent must create a nested browsing context, and then process the iframe attributes for the "first time"."
I'm not saying this isn't a Gecko bug
I'm just explaining what happens
per spec the second about:blank shouldn't be there
JonathanNeal: hsivonen will probably mark your bug to be a dup of some old Gecko bug
smaug____: interestingly enough, i don’t think the example you provided works in any browser except Firefox.
hmm, it doesn't in chromium
that is a chromium bug then
Considering what you said, it’s even more wild! http://jsfiddle.net/nft8puq5/2/
( different bug than what we have been discussing )
Look, addEventListener firing on the iframe that is not there.
I guess it’s just weird that the iframe’s document refreshes, is all. that does not make sense, that it would load one document and then another.
the spec explicitly says "A load event is also fired at the iframe element when it is created if no other data is loaded in it."
JonathanNeal: yeah, that is a Gecko bug, and load event firing incorrectly is a blink bug
smaug____: "if no other data is loaded” not sure what that means, but if i give the iframe data, it definitely ignores it, and also fires the load event.
Thanks so much for finding it in the spec though.
JonathanNeal: how did you manage to paste a link to a 2012 version of html5 spec ;)
we're certainly not trying to implement that one
Google.

JonathanNeal: I didn't check in a debugger, but it seems to me that you do the stuff you do on Gecko's docshell-created about:blank. Then the event loop spins and the old HTML parser, which we keep around only in order to remain compatible with our old about:blank behavior, overwrites the docshell-created about:blank with a parser-generated about:blank
JonathanNeal: so you end up seeing the latter, which blows away everything you did with the first one
JonathanNeal: yes, this is sad
JonathanNeal: fixing this requires some serious work
JonathanNeal: fortunately, some of that work is being done in order to support CSP better
JonathanNeal: when the CSP stuff is done, maybe I should take another attempt at fixing about:blank
hsivonen: you need to reopen bugs if you want Hixie to see your comment
Hixie: what's your time table for fixing developers.whatwg.org?
Hixie: it's the new TR at this point :-P
oh burrrrrn
zcorpan: Makes sense. Web developers obviously can't program to a moving target.   :]

hsivonen: I'm meeting with Makoto Murata this week to discuss him contributing a mechanism for making the error strings in the HTML5 datatype library localizable. I think he wants it for use in the epub checker.
hsivonen: whatever we might happen come up with, I'll make sure to get it to you for discussion before he does any work on implementing it
hsivonen: to be clear, right now, right now he's only planning/wanting to contribute something for the error messages emitted from the datatype code
hsivonen: though if we're going to OK it, I guess we should try to make sure it's generally applicable to as much of the rest of the error-emitting code elsewhere as possible
odinho: Can they program to a stationary target?
jgraham: Or indeed any target?
MikeSmith: OK. makes sense
Anyone here happen to be good with wireless routers? We have a "Technicolor TC7200" from the cable provider. Would buying something new extend the range?
I was thinking of maybe getting an AirPort Time Capsule so we can do backups and such too
annevk: Not really, but I got a few for the new offices. The two tips I got were: 5GHz is your friend. Skip the consumer grade stuff.
Ended up with Cisco Aironet 2602i.
annevk: i wouldn't consider myself good but i researched it a bit last time i needed to buy one and ended up with ASUS RT-N66U (i think), which has coverage all over my garden
(but apparently its NTFS impl is broken so don't plug in an external drive formatted as NFTS to it)
wilhelm: I wonder if my Xbox 360 can do 5GHz
wilhelm: we also have an iPhone 4 and a Macbook Pro from 2010 or so in the mix
zcorpan: garden sounds nice :-)
annevk: yep
we can see a park, but no way I can make wifi work there
wilhelm: that shit's expensive
annevk: you sure? there are 1km range routers
ooh

"The RT-N66U dual-band wireless router from ASUS brings to the fore super-fast connectivity with up to 450 Mbps per band simultaneously. It works in both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz, and supports up to a massive 300,000 concurrent data sessions - approximately 20 times the capacity of mainstream routers."
that one is a bit cheaper as well
you can have two 2.4 GHz networks, so i have one guest network that only has internet access
annevk: Yes. The ones I have are for the office. (c:
zcorpan: brilliant
Still not enough to pass through a few layers of 1928-style reinforced concrete, though. :D
wilhelm: we're not all based in the bunkers of Oslo
Well metal in the walls seems like it would be the most effective thing in blocking the signal
Which doesn't just mean thick concrete
Hmm, I just found out I could set bandwidth to 40MHz
jgraham: It's either metal, or something else that bends space-time. This is a functionalist building from the 1920s. Nice place, big windows, just downtown. Zero radio communication between rooms.
That seems to have helped boost things up a bit, maybe I don't need new stuff for now
hsivonen: nice work on getting those encoding changes landed, hoping they'll stick :-)
zcorpan: empty string already has a meaning for languages
annevk: is the meaning wrong for what we want here?
zcorpan: unknown language != user's language
zcorpan: although apparently there's no such thing as a tag for the user's language
annevk: user's language is not known by the author :-)
annevk: lang="" is equivalent to not specifying lang anywhere, isn't it?
zcorpan: from that perspective...
zcorpan: seems reasonable, chatting with Richard on Skype, but he's a bit busy
annevk: so i am learning that multipart formdata parsing is not well-specified, but larry is trying to make it so, without much traction? how does this impact fetch and FormData?

Domenic: there's https://github.com/masinter/multipart-form-data/ but per https://github.com/masinter/multipart-form-data/issues/17#issuecomment-48077041 it's not clear whether he's interested in defining what we need in the end
Domenic: the impact is that multipart/form-data parsing is somewhat muddy and might differ until we clearly define the rules
Domenic: not so different from user agents not agreeing on how to implement URLs... that seems a bit more significant if you ask me
right
Domenic: I hope someone will pick it up, if nobody does, I guess I will at some point
annevk: does it make sense for you to write the algorithms for converting things into larry's format?
Domenic: that sounds like the theoretical let's write a URL spec on top of RFC 3986 approach, which is not very attractive from an engineering standpoint
yeah, i dunno
The format is not very complicated. Either Larry makes it work or someone else will. No big deal I think
https://twitter.com/llaamm1991/status/516947782478102528 hmm
poor child.

interesting attacks

annevk: is there a https url?

annevk: ah ok. sure

TabAtkins: how do i tell bikeshed to prefer EDs
tobie: is there a reason WebIDL doesn't point to the ED for the href, if specref prefers "latest and greatest"?
Domenic: README predates any of the automation we've added since then.
Domenic: Yeah, but it wasn't using EDs either back then.
I actually started a thread on the topic of what it was folks really wanted on specprod@ a while back.
Domenic: it wasn't really conclusive. :)
Domenic: given that I actually need to solve that problem for me pretty much as we speak, I'm happy to reopen the conversation.
Else, I'll just add an EDDraft prop to the returned object and let folks deal with it as they please.
I mean, this is mainly a Bikeshed level concern for me right now
Domenic: I understand. The data's currently not exposed on Specref though.
So I'm not sure what Bikeshed can do about that.
Unless Bikeshed grabs the JSON directly from the repo rather than from the API.

what's the value of the "This version" line?
When writing a spec: if I have a term with a definition that can be linked to, should every single occurrence of the term be linked? Only the first of the paragraph? Some other criteria?
also, <hgroup> only takes <hx> children, i'm not sure what you mean
do you have a sample of what you want to do?
like in live dom viewer or something
SimonSapin: i've started just linking every case cos it's easier to reason about when making edits
Hixie: https://url.spec.whatwg.org/ has an example
well that's non-conforming
i think maybe you want <header> intead of <hgroup>?
but then the <h2> is no longer grouped
perhaps I should upgrade the link to be a heading?
Domenic: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/spec-prod/2014AprJun/0027.html
yeah i wouldn't use <h2> if you went that route
you could make the link a heading
but the real question
is why bother with the url at all
it's a bit of a leftover from the old days, but okay
let's nuke it and see how people react

nobody outside of #whatwg while i was editing it has said anything at all about the header of the html spec
annevk: interesting, no editor
Domenic: put it in ack
Domenic: same with license
not sure about license in ack but didn't feel like a whole new chapter either

"latest" != "ed" in specref
there is no latest.

Domenic: needs vetting by WG on a teleconference before you can call it stable

you typoed "stale"

yes it should
I don't know why it's showing up as a sites.goole.com URL
it should just work as is
note that all openwebfoundation.org links redirect
noted. and that looks like a bug.
okay, so I'll restore the OWF link for now hoping it'll get fixed
it will be moved to ack
no need to have this on top
tantek: see https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#acknowledgments

tantek: "Per CC0, to the extent possible under law, the editor has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this work. In addition, as of 30 September 2014, the editor has made this specification available under the Open Web Foundation Agreement Version 1.0." is the text I plan on using from now on
tantek: the previous iteration had a plain text version of the link as well, but that seems like bullshit
+1 that
doesn't OWFa 1.0 require a new version of the license with each edit?
and a signature, etc?
i don't understand what it means to say "the editor has made this specification available under the Open Web Foundation Agreement Version 1.0."
also, is it you who is granting your patents, or is it mozilla?
ask tantek
tantek: ^
Domenic: that said, PR welcomed granted it doesn't make all Urls suddenly EDs (as the last thing I want is another of those sterile discussions directly in my inbox).
annevk: you're the one saying it, i'd hope that you would be able to answer those questions too :-)

Hixie: I think it's just me

annevk: so do you print the agreement with each commit and store the signed contracts each time?
I don't
if that's required, I might opt to remove it again I guess; Domenic / tantek?
so what do you mean by "the editor has made this specification available under the..."?
i mean, read the license
annevk: I know very little besides "more open good" :)
so much work :/
see in particular section 8.8
i don't really understand what OWFa 1.0 adds, if you're already using CC0
doesn't CC0 not cover patents at all
in fact, I don't understand how you can both use CC0 and OWFa, doesn't OWFa section 2.1 mean nothing at all if CC0 is used?
Domenic: neither does OWFa 1.0, unless Anne owns patents he hasn't told us about
Hixie: I think the idea is to provide assurance that you don't claim any patents without the reader having to know the editor's patent portfolio
Hixie, not AFAIK
Domenic: then I think the CG CLA is probably a better mechanism
tantek: not AFAIK what?
Domenic: since, in particular, it doesn't require that you sign a piece of paper with each contribution
CLA fails in practice
splitting CLA and FSA was a mistake
the OWF licenses have the exact same split
so instead, we switched the model where with each version/commit/date you re-agree to the FSA
which is what the boilerplate has
Hixie, I know, and that's why we ignore the CLA half
it's useless
Hixie, the language about "editor has made this specification available under the Open Web Foundation Agreement Version 1.0. " is good enough per our legal review.
no need to print stuff out and fax things etc.
i don't understand how your lawyers interpret 8.8 or 2.1
IANAL so I'm not worried about it
got it reviewed, good enough, moving forward.
i'm not in the slightest bit worried, i just think it's bogus :-)
if you have specific legal issues from your lawyers we can have them talk to ours
otherwise, I don't care to spend time on micromanaging license contents
i'm pretty sure my lawyers don't care either :-)
well then, let's keep moving forward
doesn't stop it from being bogus :-)
as you've pointed out, we've got real bugs to fix :)
Hixie - IIRC you think all patents are bogus :P
different meaning of the term
anyway. the OWFa stuff imho is pointless. if we want to resign the FSA each time then we should just do that with the CG FSA, which is much more sound.
annevk: any news on https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=974341 ?
Hixie, the OWFa stuff gives us a patent commitment *independent of W3C*
that's why it's useful
the CG FSA is purely for "playing nice with W3C"
IMO
what's it got to do with the w3c other than that they host it
Hixie: no
tantek: hmm, no, FSA gives us much more
annevk: should i wontfix the relevant spec bugs, or is this something that's still in the cards?
tantek: e.g. for URL we have commitments from Mozilla and Google
and opera
and darobin, now!

k

annevk - the *CG* gives us much more
(it would be mildly clearer if you used the patent-only one, but i don't see how it's worth any more than just "I don't have any patents, by the way.")
we could independently try to get other companies to sign OWFa FSA for WHATWG specs
*independently* of W3C
who cares if it's independent of the w3c
i'm not against the w3c, i'm against the w3c's actions that harm interoperability.
the CGs and the FSAs don't harm interoperability. They're great.
